questions.text: A male child was brought in Casualty with previous history of URTI and headache. He currently has fever, fatigue and pain on walking for which USG and joint aspiration were done before giving antibiotics. A lytic lesion was seen on the lower end of the femur. The peripheral smear shows the following finding. What is the most probable organism that can be isolated from the joint aspirate?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Salmonella Given case is a typical scenario of acute Osteomyelitis in a sickle cell anemia patient. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism (overall) However, in cases of sickle cell anemia –salmonella is the most common causative organism and hence, A is the correct choice.

Extraedge:

OTHER CAUSES OF OSTEOMYELITIS: IV drug abusers- Pseudomonas [ Option D ] Sickle cell disease- Salmonella (in diaphysis) Prolonged parenteral therapy- Fungal infections Human bite- Eikenella Animal bites- Pasteurella Infants- Streptococcus Group B [ Option C ]

questions.text: An Alcoholic patient presented with white patches in the oral cavity as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leukoplakia The most commonly described premalignant oral lesions are leukoplakia, Erythroplakia, lichen planus, and submucous fibrosis. Hence, it is essential to differentiate between these lesions. The given image shows oral mucosal white patches with malignancy potential that cannot be scraped off which is a significant pointer for oral Leukoplakia. Associated conditions: squamous cell carcinoma Risk factors: Tobacco use Alcohol use Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection Histopathology of oral leukoplakia often reveals hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis with varying degrees of inflammation. Hyperplastic epithelium may be present, in addition to mild, moderate, or severe dysplasia. Differentials: Oral hairy leukoplakia Differentiating factors: seen in immunocompromised patients and caused by Epstein-Barr virus Pseudomembranous candidiasis] Differentiating factors: can be scraped off

Highyeild:

Oral submucous fibrosis is a separate entity that is caused specifically by betel nut use. Chronic betel quid use results in submucosal fibrosis, leading to progressive oral cavity scarring leading to ulceration, xerostomia, trismus, dysphagia, or odynophagia. Oral submucous fibrosis may present in isolation but can also be found concurrently with leukoplakia or Erythroplakia. It is characterized by abnormal collagen deposition. It is a precancerous disorder and transforms into a malignant tumor in 1.5–15% of all cases. Erythroplakia often has similar features on histological evaluation, including varying degrees of dysplasia; Erythroplakia lesions harbor carcinoma more frequently than leukoplakic lesions. Leukoplakia will present as a white patch or plaque in the oral cavity, which cannot be wiped off, whereas Erythroplakia may present as a firm red patch or plaque; both are usually non-tender lesions. The lesion can be diffuse or well-circumscribed and may involve the wet border of the lip, floor of the mouth, oral tongue, or buccal mucosa. Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition that typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals and is thought to be secondary to a bactericidal defect in macrophages. Malakoplakia typically affects the urinary tract, but the involvement of nearly every organ system has been reported.

questions.text: A 20 year female working in a school in a rural area developed rice watery diarrhea. The organism responsible for this condition acts via which receptor?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GM 1 Gangliosidase Receptor MOA of cholera toxin: GM 1 ganglioside receptor GM1 has important physiological properties and impacts neuronal plasticity and repair mechanisms, and the release of neurotrophins in the brain . Besides its function in the physiology of the brain, GM1 acts as the site of binding for both cholera toxin and E. coli heat-labile enterotoxin (Traveller's diarrhea).

Highyeild:

Cholera toxin (CT) is a heterodimer composed of 5 B subunits that encircle a single A subunit. The B subunit is responsible for binding to the monoganglioside GM1 receptor on intestinal epithelial cells. The A subunit is responsible for activation of adenylate cyclase located on the basolateral cellular membrane. Cyclic AMP (cAMP) activates protein kinase A, which causes the opening of ion channels in the membrane, leading to chloride and bicarbonate secretion by intestinal crypt cells and disruption in absorption by villus cells. V. cholerae also produces additional toxins that may contribute to diseases, including the zonula occludens toxin, that alter intestinal permeability by acting on intestinal epithelial cell tight junctions, and the accessory cholera enterotoxin.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: GM2 gangliosidoses are a group of pathologies characterized by GM2 ganglioside accumulation into the lysosome due to mutations on the genes encoding for the β-hexosaminidases subunits or the GM2 activator protein. Three GM2 gangliosidoses have been described: Tay–Sachs disease, Sandhoff disease, and the AB variant. Option C: Serum antibody binding to GD 1a ganglioside is associated with motor neuropathy syndromes. Option D: Glucocerebrosidase deficiency leads to Gaucher’s disease. It is characterized by the presence of clinical or radiographic evidence of bone disease (osteopenia, focal lytic or sclerotic lesions, and osteonecrosis), hepatosplenomegaly, anemia and thrombocytopenia, lung disease, and the absence of primary central nervous system disease.

questions.text: A Farmer presented with multiple sinuses with a discharging granule on the leg. The granules were crushed and examined. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Can be caused by Bacteria and Fungi

options.label: B
options.text: Involve Skin only. No Deeper Tissue Involvement

questions.correct_answer: A. Can be caused by Bacteria and Fungi
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Can be caused by Bacteria and Fungi Mycetoma mycetes or Madhura foot is caused by fungal and bacterial infection. These bacteria and fungi may enter the body through a break in the skin, often on a person’s foot. The resulting infection causes firm, usually painless but debilitating masses under the skin that can eventually affect the underlying bone. Clinical features include chronic subcutaneous swelling (option B) Bacterial: Actinomycetes Yellow granules - Actinomadura madurae (MC), Actinomyces, nocardia. Red granules seen in Actinomadura pelletri Fungal: Eumycetoma Black granules- Madurella mycetomatis White granules-Pseudallescheria boydii Involves skin and subcutaneous tissues Lymphocyte accumulation is absent (option C), no lymph drainage and so accumulation may lead to osteolytic lesion. Direct invasion is seen, no hematogenous spread ( option D). The treatment for mycetoma depends on whether it is caused by bacteria (actinomycetoma) or fungi (eumycetoma). Actinomycetoma is usually treatable with antibiotics, and surgery is usually not needed. Eumycetoma is usually treated with long-term antifungal medicine, but treatment may not be completely effective. In this case, surgery or amputation are sometimes needed to cut away the infected tissue.

questions.text: A woodworker presented with chronic localised infection of the skin on lower legs and feet which are irregular, rough, cauliflower like lesions. Microscopy of biopsy shows copper penny bodies. What is the etiological agent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chromoblastomycosis Chromoblastomycosis aka Verrucous Dermatitis is caused by wood prick. Involves skin and subcutaneous tissues forming warty lesions Biopsy will reveal brown colored globose bodies ,sclerotic bodies or medlar bodies which shows copper penny appearance.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Phaeohyphomycosis refers to infections due to a large group of heterogenous organisms called "dematiaceous" or "melanized" fungi. These fungi are distinguished by the predominance of melanin in their cell walls, which likely acts as a virulence factor. Option C: Sporothrix schenckii causes Sporotrichosis or Rose gardeners disease. Usually caused by thorn prick. It is a dimorphic fungus. Spreads via lymphatics so multiple ulcers or vesicles can be seen. Option D: Mycetoma or Madura foot is a bacterial or fungal infection. Discharging sinuses with granules can be seen. Fungal-Eumycetoma; Bacterial-Actinomycetes

questions.text: Which of the following is the best way to diagnose a clostridium associated diarrhea?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Toxin Demonstration DIAGNOSIS The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria: (1) diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause plus (2) detection of toxin A or B in the stool, detection of toxin-producing C. difficile in the stool by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT; e.g., polymerase chain reaction [PCR]) or by culture, or visualization of pseudomembranes in the colon.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - PMC is a more advanced form of CDI and is visualized at endoscopy in only ~50% of patients with diarrhea who have a positive stool culture and toxin assay for C. difficile. Option C - Endoscopy is a rapid diagnostic tool in seriously ill patients with suspected PMC and an acute abdomen, but a negative result in this examination does not rule out CDI. Blood culture is not effective.

Extraedge:

TABLE 129-1 Relative Sensitivity and Specificity of Diagnostic Tests for Clostridium difficile Infection (CDI) TYPE OF TEST RELATIVE SENSITIVITYRELATIVE SENSITIVITY RELATIVE SPECIFICITY COMMENT Stool culture for C. difficile ++++ +++ Most sensitive test; specificity of ++++ if the C. difficile isolate tests positive for toxin turnaround time too slow for practical use Cell culture cytotoxin test on stool +++ ++++ With clinical data, is diagnostic of CDI; highly specific but not as sensitive as stool culture; slow turnaround time Enzyme immunoassay for toxins A and Bin stool +++to+++ +++ With clinical data, is diagnostic of CDI; rapid results, but not as sensitive as stool culture or cell culture cytotoxin test Enzyme immunoassay for C. difficile common antigen in stool +++to++++ +++ Detects glutamate dehydrogenase found intoxigenic and nontoxigenic strains of C. difficile and other stool organisms; more sensitive and less specific than enzyme immunoassay for toxins; requires confirmation with a toxin test: rapid results Nucleic acid amplification tests for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool ++++ +++ Detects toxigenic C. difficile in stool; widely used in US. for clinical testing more sensitive than enzyme immunoassay toxin testing marked increase in CDI diagnoses when implemented Colonoscopy of sigmoовору + ++++ Highly specific pseudomembranes are seen insensitive compared with other tests

questions.text: A 24 yr old male who recently returned from Africa reported with jaundice and hemorrhagic fever. Histology reveals the presence of Torres bodies. Symptomatic treatment was given but the patient died. Which strain of the vaccine must have prevented this occurrence?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

17D Strain Above case points to the diagnosis of Yellow fever. The yellow fever virus is an Arbovirus of the Flavivirus genus and is transmitted by Aedes species of mosquitoes. 17D strain Vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine developed for yellow fever.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - Danish 1331 strain is used in BCG vaccine. Option B - Jeryll Lynn strain is used in mumps vaccine. Option C - Nakayama strain is used in the JE vaccine.

questions.text: A military person in a crowded military basement presented with rash on body, sparing palms and soles. On examination lice found on examination. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pediculosis Corporis Pediculosis corporis is caused by body lice. Unlike head and pubic lice, body lice do not live on the skin but rather live and lay their eggs in stitches of clothing or bedding, moving to the skin only to feed. Hence in a military person palm and soles are spared.

Highyeild:

The most significant difference between body and head lice is the distinct ability of body lice to transmit the bacterial diseases of trench fever, relapsing fever, and epidemic typhus to humans.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: Scabies is caused by Sarcoptes scabiei. Usually leaves an irregular tract where the mite burrows Option C: Pityriasis Rosea is triggered by viral infections (most common cause-herpes). Round or oval scaly lesions can be seen on centripetal region. Classically, it begins with a single red and slightly scaly area known as a "herald patch". This is then followed, days to weeks later, by a rash of many similar but smaller round or oval lesions, mainly on the trunk and upper limbs. About 20% of cases show atypical deviations from this pattern. It usually lasts less than three months and goes away without treatment. Option D: Cutaneous Leishmaniasis is caused by a bite of Phlebotomus sand fly. It typically occurs at the site of inoculation and is the most common form of leishmaniasis Solitary lesions are typical, but multiple lesions do occur The initial lesion is a small red papule, which gradually enlarges up to 2 cm in diameter Central ulceration is typical Ulcers can be moist and exude pus or dry with a crusty scab Lesions are usually painless, and most resolve spontaneously often leaving residual atrophic scarring Lesion can be seen on exposed area, no sparing of palms and soles.

questions.text: A 30 year old military jawan complains of fever, vomiting, rash and myalgia. Similar complaints are found in others. There was an absence of rash in palms and soles. All were suffering from an infestation of lice. What is the causative agent of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rickettsia Prowazeki Louse infestation is found in Epidemic typhus and trench fever Sparing of palms and soles is characteristic of epidemic typhus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - Rickettsia conorii (tick) – Indian tick typhus Option: B - Rickettsia Akari (mite) – rickettsial pox Rickettsia Prowazeki (louse) – epidemic typhus Option: D - Rickettsia typhi (Flea) – endemic typhus

questions.text: Identify the Microfilaria with a sheath surrounding it and two big nuclei at its tail tip?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Brugia Malayi Microfilaria with a sheath surrounding it and two big nuclei at its tail tip is Brugia malayi.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - The microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are sheathed and they have a gently curved body, and a tail that is tapered to a point. Option: C - Loa loa microfilariae are sheathed and the tail is tapered and nuclei extend to the tip of the tail. Option: D - Onchocerca microfilariae: The tail tapers to a point and is often sharply bent. The nuclei do not extend to the tip of the tail.

questions.text: A woman with clinical history of diarrhea is on broad spectrum antibiotic therapy. Which of the following is not true regarding C. difficile ?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral Fidaxomicin can be used for C. difficile

options.label: B
options.text: Toxin Assay is used for Diagnosis

options.label: C
options.text: C. difficile can be confirmed by using IgM Assay

options.label: D
options.text: C. difficile is normal commensals of Small Intestine

questions.correct_answer: C. C. difficile can be confirmed by using IgM Assay
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C. difficile can be confirmed by using IgM Assay

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - Oral Fidaxomicin can be used for C. difficile. Definitive treatment is fecal transplantation in intestines. Option: B - Toxin assay of enterotoxin A and Cytotoxin B can be done on Hela-Hep 2 cell line to establish . Pathogenesis of clostridium associated diarrhea is toxin production not immune related hence IgM assays are not useful. Option: D - Clostridium are normal commensals of the small intestine. right option exp not given

questions.text: A person got admitted in the hospital for sepsis treated with antibiotics for long term, manifested with diarrhea and dehydration. Which investigation is preferred ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GDH Ag and Exotoxins Long term treatment with antibiotics points to Clostridium difficile. Glutamate dehydrogenase enzyme Ag and exotoxins are used to determine C. difficile infection.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A and B - Antigen and culture alone are not definitive since C. difficile are normal commensals of small intestines. Option D - Microscopic Examination of the Stool - not the preferred investigation.

questions.text: A patient presented with annular lesions and central clearing on axilla. Culture on SDA revealed whitish flat to slightly raised colonies showing Red pigment producing pencil shaped Macroconidia. What is the most likely causative organism ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trichophyton Rubrum Trichophyton rubrum is a dermatophytic fungus in the phylum Ascomycota. It is an exclusively clonal, anthropophilic saprotroph that colonizes the upper layers of dead skin, and is the most common cause of athlete's foot, fungal infection of nail, jock itch, and ringworm worldwide. The colonies are velvety and contain deep red velvety pigment on their reverse side. Trichophyton rubrum grows slowly in culture with sparse production of teardrop or peg-shaped microconidia laterally on fertile hyphae . Macroconidia, when present, are smooth-walled and narrowly club-shaped, although most isolates lack macroconidia . Growth is inhibited in the presence of certain sulfur-, nitrogen- and phosphorus-containing compounds. Pencil shaped macroconidia are typically seen. Approximately 80–93% of chronic dermatophyte infections in many parts of the developed world are thought to be caused by rubrum including cases of tinea pedis(foot), tinea unguium(nail), tinea manum (hand), tinea cruris(groin), and tinea corporis(arms and leg), as well as some cases of tinea barbae(beard). Trichophyton rubrum has also been known to cause folliculitis in which case it is characterized by fungal element in follicles and foreign body giant cells in the dermis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. violaceum is a slow growing organism with waxy (and not velvety unlike in T. rubrum) colonies that produce purple pigmentation (hence the name). It is an anthropophilic dermatophyte causing mainly tinea capitis, a fungal infection of the scalp occurring particularly in children and adolescents , and occasionally tinea corporis. Option: C. Trichophyton tonsurans may be identified through analysis of its fast-growing colonies. Colonies tend to be flat, powdery, and yellow with a reddish undercolour. It develops into a folded colony, and may vary in colour On Sabouraud agar the fungus grows peripherally and develops into a flatter, creamy disk with raised edges. Trichophyton tonsurans also produces many inflated, pear-shaped microconidia , borne on matchstick-like stalks. Trichophyton tonsurans is the most common causal organism of tinea capitis, representing greater than 90% of cases; followed by Microsporum canis , and M . audouinii . The disease varies from noninflamed scaling patches to inflamed, pustule-studded plaques (kerion) that may leave scars. Tinea capitis can appear as seborrheic-like dermatitis with minimal inflammation, patchy alopecia with broken hair shafts leaving residual black stumps (“black dot” ringworm). Occipital lymph nodes are often present. A more severe infection with indurated, boggy plaques (kerion) covered with pustules and crusting, accompanied by lymphadenopathy , can result in scarring. Option: D. - Trichophyton Schoenleinii - Favus or tinea favosa is in most cases a severe form of tinea capitis. It is caused by the dermatophyte fungus Trichophyton schoenleinii and results in a honeycomb destruction of the hair shaft. Although rare, it may sometimes occur as onychomycosis, tinea barbae, or tinea corporis.

questions.text: A HIV patient presented with fever, cough and breathlessness. The isolated organism was a fungi showing yeast form at 37 C and mould form at 25 C as shown in the image. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Talaromyces Marneffi Talaromycosis is an infection caused by the fungus Talaromyces marneffei . the image is suggestive of Talaromyces marneffei used to be called Penicillium marneffei , and talaromycosis used to be called penicilliosis. Talaromycosis affects people who live in or visit Southeast Asia, southern China, or eastern India. usually associated with HIV/AIDS, or another immunocompromised condition.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - Pneumocystis - Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia is a fungal infection of the lungs. The disease used to be called Pneumocystis carinii or PCP pneumonia. AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) is caused by HIV (human immunodeficiency virus), and is a syndrome that leaves the body vulnerable to a host of life-threatening illnesses. Option: C - Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus that causes blastomycosis, an invasive and often serious fungal infection found occasionally in humans and other animals. It lives in soil and wet, decaying wood, often in an area close to a waterway such as a lake, river or stream. Option: D - Coccidioides immitis is a pathogenic fungus that resides in the soil in certain parts of the southwestern United States, northern Mexico, and a few other areas in the Western Hemisphere.

questions.text: A truck driver manifested with pneumonia. Sample histopathology showed septate hyphae with dichotomous branching (acute angle branching) at 45o as shown in the image. What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aspergillus Points in favor of aspergillus Septate hyphae Dichotomous branching Acute angled (mostly 45 o C)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A and C - Broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching seen in members of Zygomycetes. i.e Rhizopus and Mucor Option B - Candida: Gram-positive oval budding yeast cell with pseudohyphae.

questions.text: A female presented with curdy white discharge sample microscopy showed budding yeast cell with pseudohyphae. Which medium is used to differentiate the species of the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chromagar Different species of candida shows different color albicans – light green dubiliensis – dark green tropicalis – metallic blue krusei – pink C. parapsilosis - cream

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - SDA - Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA) is a non-selective isolation medium used for the growth and maintenance of pathogenic and non-pathogenic fungi from clinical and nonclinical specimens. It is also used for recovery and total counting of yeasts and molds in environmental monitoring. Option: B - Bird Seed Agar - Bird Seed Agar is a solid medium used for selective and differential isolation of Cryptococcus neoformans from clinical specimens. Option: C - PDA - Potato Dextrose Agar (PDA) is used for the cultivation of fungi. Potato Dextrose Agar (PDA) is a general purpose medium for yeasts and molds that can be supplemented with acid or antibiotics to inhibit bacterial growth. It is recommended for plate count methods for foods, dairy products and testing cosmetics.

questions.text: A patient presented with a complaint of fever, sore throat and calf pain for one week. On examination he has jaundice, subconjunctival suffusion and tender hepatomegaly. There is no history of travel however he is a sewer worker. No history of chills, rigors and anorexia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leptospirosis Given a history of fever, sore throat and especially calf pain with a history of sewer worker points to Leptospirosis . Leptospirosis affects multiple organs if left untreated and can cause liver damage, kidney damage and eventually death.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - Chikungunya most commonly presents with fever associated with joint pains in wrists, knee and ankle. These typically occur two to twelve days after exposure. Symptoms usually improve within a week; however, occasionally the joint pain may last for months or years. Option: C - Hepatic encephalopathy presents with symptoms such as confused state, anxiety, seizures or coma. Option: D - Dengue fever presents with fever, back pain, chills, petechial rashes.
